{{TennisEventInfo|2009|Ethias Trophy| | date= 5 – 11 October | edition=5th | location=[[Mons]], [[Belgium]] | champs={{flagicon|SRB}} [[Janko Tipsarević]] | champd={{flagicon|UZB}} [[Denis Istomin]] / {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Evgeny Korolev]] }} The '''2009 [[Ethias Trophy]]''' was a professional [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Tennis court#Hard courts|indoor hard courts]]. It was the fifth edition of the tournament which was part of the [[Tretorn SERIE+]] of the [[2009 ATP Challenger Tour]]. It took place in [[Mons]], [[Belgium]] between 5 and 11 October 2009. ==Singles main draw entrants== ===Seeds=== {|class="sortable wikitable" |- ! width="70"| Country ! width="175"| Player ! Rank1 ! Seed |- |{{flag|SRB}} |[[Janko Tipsarević]] |55 |1 |- |{{flag|ITA}} |[[Simone Bolelli]] |63 |2 |- |{{flag|RUS}} |[[Evgeny Korolev]] |66 |3 |- |{{flag|FRA}} |[[Marc Gicquel]] |68 |4 |- |{{flag|RUS}} |[[Teymuraz Gabashvili]] |80 |5 |- |{{flag|BEL}} |[[Olivier Rochus]] |81 |6 |- |{{flag|FRA}} |[[Florent Serra]] |82 |7 |- |{{flag|BEL}} |[[Christophe Rochus]] |84 |8 |} * Rankings are as of September 28, 2009. ===Other Entrants=== The following players received wildcards into the singles main draw: * {{flagicon|BEL}} [[Ruben Bemelmans]] * {{flagicon|BEL}} [[Arthur De Greef (tennis)|Arthur de Greef]] * {{flagicon|BEL}} [[David Goffin]] * {{flagicon|BEL}} Yannick Vandenbulcke The following players received entry from the qualifying draw: * {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Sergei Bubka (tennis)|Sergei Bubka]] * {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Jérôme Haehnel]] * {{flagicon|SVK}} [[Dominik Hrbatý]] * {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Illya Marchenko]] ==Champions== ===Singles=== {{main|2009 Ethias Trophy – Singles}} {{flagicon|SRB}} '''[[Janko Tipsarević]]''' def. {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Sergiy Stakhovsky]], 7–6(4), 6–3 ===Doubles=== {{main|2009 Ethias Trophy – Doubles}} {{flagicon|UZB}} '''[[Denis Istomin]]''' / {{flagicon|RUS}} '''[[Evgeny Korolev]]''' def. {{flagicon|COL}} [[Alejandro Falla]] / {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Teymuraz Gabashvili]], 6–7(4), 7–6(4), [11–9] ==External links== *[http://www.ethiastrophy.be/fr/news Official website] *[http://www.itftennis.com/mens/tournaments/tournamentSearch.asp ITF Search] *[http://www.protennislive.com/posting/2009/3350/x.pdf 2009 Draws]

{{Infobox recurring event | name = 2013 [[Mr. Olympia]] | logo = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | genre = [[Professional bodybuilding]] competition | begins = September 27, 2013 | ends = September 28, 2013 | venue = [[Orleans Arena]] at [[The Orleans Hotel and Casino]] | location = [[Paradise, Nevada]] | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | country = United States | last = <!-- Date of most recent event; if the event will not be held again, use {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | prev = [[2012 Mr. Olympia]] | next = [[2014 Mr. Olympia]] | participants = | attendance = | organized = [[International Federation of BodyBuilders|IFBB]] | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} The '''2013 [[Mr. Olympia]]''' contest was an [[International Federation of BodyBuilders|IFBB]] [[professional bodybuilding]] competition held September 27–28, 2013, at the [[Orleans Arena]] at [[The Orleans Hotel and Casino]] in [[Paradise, Nevada]]. It was the 49th Mr. Olympia competition held. Other events at the exhibition included the [[2013 212 Olympia Showdown|212 Olympia Showdown]], [[2013 Ms. Olympia|Ms. Olympia]], [[2013 Fitness Olympia|Fitness Olympia]], [[2013 Figure Olympia|Figure Olympia]], [[2013 Bikini Olympia|Bikini Olympia]], [[2013 Women's Physique Showdown|Women's Physique Showdown]], and [[2013 Men's Physique Showdown|Men's Physique Showdown]] contests.
==Mr. Olympia results== A total prize pool of $675,000 was awarded.<ref>{{cite web|last=IFBB Pro League Staff|url=http://www.ifbbpro.com/news/2013-olympia-prize-money-1000000/|title=2013 Olympia Prize|publisher=[[International Federation of BodyBuilding & Fitness|IFBB]]|date=2013-08-07|accessdate=2013-09-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131025001325/http://www.ifbbpro.com/news/2013-olympia-prize-money-1000000/|archive-date=2013-10-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=August 2015}} {{more citations needed|date=August 2015}} }} The '''{{lang|en|All Alaska Sweepstakes}}''' was an annual [[Sled dog racing|dog-sled race]] held in [[Alaska]] during April. Mushers traveled from [[Nome, Alaska|Nome]] to [[Candle, Alaska|Candle]], traveling along the [[Arctic Ocean|Bering Strait]], and then return to Nome. Between 1908 and 1917 the race was held ten times. Due to the [[United States]]' involvement in the [[World War I|Great War]] and new [[List of sled dog races|dog-sled races]] elsewhere in [[North America]], the race was discontinued. Two commemorative events occurred in 1983 and 2008, to mark the 75th and 100th anniversaries of the first race, respectively. == History == [[File:All_Alaska_Sweepstakes_Race.JPG|thumb|right|Start of 1915 {{lang|en|All Alaska Sweepstakes}}]] In 1907, the local administrators of the Nome Kennel Club in [[Nome, Alaska]], developed plans for a long-distance dog-sled race that followed a route along the Bering Strait. The first race, named the All Alaska Sweepstakes, took place in the spring of 1908. The competition was held annually until the final race in 1917. To be in the race, participants were required to register by November. Each team had anywhere from 10 to 20 dogs. The race started in [[Nome, Alaska|Nome]] and followed [[Telegraphy|telegraphic]] lines to [[Candle, Alaska|Candle]], Alaska, before retracing the route to Nome. The telegraphic lines enabled the mushers to communicate their checkpoint times and ranks to the media. The stop numbers and places were uncontrolled, so stewards were placed at each stop along the journey to resupply teams. [[Mushing|Mushers]] were required to finish the race with as many dogs as they started with, whether they were alive, injured or dead. This rule encouraged participants to take adequate care of their dogs, since an injured or dead dog would be a great drawback. To help minimize the weight on each sled, a minimum amount of items such as clothes, water and shoes for the dogs was loaded. == Winners == {| class="wikitable" ! Year ! Musher ! State ([[United States]]) or
birth country
! Time |- |1908 |John Hegness |[[Image:Flag of Norway.svg|25px]] [[Norway]] |119 hours 15 minutes 12 seconds |- |1909 |Allan A. « Scotty » Allan |[[Image:Flag of Scotland.svg|25px]] [[Scotland]] |82 hours 2 minutes 41 seconds |- |1910 |John Johnson |[[Image:Flag of Finland.svg|25px]] [[Finland]] |74 hours 14 minutes 37 seconds |- |1911 |Allan A. « Scotty » Allan (2) |[[Image:Flag of Scotland.svg|25px]] [[Scotland]] |80 hours 49 minutes 41 seconds |- |1912 |Allan A. « Scotty » Allan (3) |[[Image:Flag of Scotland.svg|25px]] [[Scotland]] |87 hours 27 minutes 46 seconds |- |1913 |Fay Delzene |[[Image:Flag of Iowa.svg|25px]] [[Iowa]] |75 hours 42 minutes 27 seconds |- |1914 |John Johnson (2) |[[Image:Flag of Finland.svg|25px]] [[Finland]] |81 hours 3 minutes 45 seconds |- |1915 |[[Leonhard Seppala]] |[[Image:Flag of Norway.svg|25px]] [[Norway]] |78 hours 44 minutes 57 seconds |- |1916 |[[Leonhard Seppala]] (2) |[[Image:Flag of Norway.svg|25px]] [[Norway]] |80 hours 38 minutes 5 seconds |- |1917 |[[Leonhard Seppala]] (3) |[[Image:Flag of Norway.svg|25px]] [[Norway]] |113 hours |- |1983 |[[Rick Swenson]] |[[Image:Flag of Minnesota.svg|25px]] [[Minnesota]] |84 hours 42 minutes 4 seconds |- |2008 |[[Mitch Seavey]] |[[Image:Flag of Alaska.svg|25px]] [[Alaska]] |61 hours 29 minutes 45 seconds |} == Bibliography == * {{cite web|url=http://www.adn.com/article/all-alaska-sweepstakes/ |title=The All Alaska Sweepstakes|first1= Helen| last1= Hegener| date=2009-12-14| publisher=[[Alaska Dispatch News]]}} ; * {{cite web|url=http://yukondigitallibrary.ca/digitalbook/greatdogracesnome/ |title=Great dog races of Nome}} ; * {{cite web|url=http://www.nomekennelclub.com/nkchistory.htm|title=Nome Kennel Club History}}. * Gold, Men and Dogs by A.A. “Scotty” Allen ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Long-distance sled dog races}} {{Dog sports}} [[Category:Dog sledding races]] [[Category:Endurance games]] [[Category:Sports in Alaska]]

{{About|the men's team|the women's team|Bahamas women's national rugby union team}} {{Infobox rugby team | country = Bahamas | image = | imagesize = | union = | nickname = | ground = | coach = | caps = | top scorer = | most tries = | from = | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = white | pattern_ra1 = | leftarm1 = | body1 = | rightarm1 = | shorts1 = | socks1 = | first = {{ru|BER}} 24 - 3 {{ru-rt|BAH}}
(22 March 1997) | bigwin = {{ru|BAH}} 42 - 5 {{ru-rt|Dominican Republic}}
(3 June 2017) | bigloss = {{ru|BAR}} 52 - 3 {{ru-rt|BAH}}
(1 October 2005) | No World cup apps = }} The '''Bahamas national rugby union team''' represent the [[Bahamas]] in the sport of [[rugby union]]. The team have thus far not qualified for a [[Rugby World Cup]], but have participated in qualifying tournament. The nation is classified as tier three by the [[International Rugby Board]] (IRB). ==History== The Bahamas made their international debut on March 22, 1997 in a match against [[Bermuda national rugby union team|Bermuda]]. Bermuda won the contest 24 points to 3. The Bahamas played [[Barbados national rugby union team|Barbados]] that April, and in the process won their first international; defeating Barbados 37-23. The team played three internationals during October 1998; although the Bahamas lost all three games, against Bermuda, [[Trinidad & Tobago national rugby union team|Trinidad & Tobago]] and [[Jamaica national rugby union team|Jamaica]]. The Bahamas compete in the [[Caribbean Championship]], a tournament which includes [[Antigua and Barbuda national rugby union team|Antigua]], [[Trinidad and Tobago national rugby union team|Trinidad and Tobago]], the [[Cayman Islands national rugby union team|Cayman Islands]], [[Jamaica national rugby union team|Jamaica]], the [[Bermuda national rugby union team|Bermuda]], [[British Virgin Islands national rugby union team|British Virgin Islands]], and [[Guyana national rugby union team|Guyana]].Bath, Richard (ed.) ''The Complete Book of Rugby'' (Seven Oaks Ltd, 1997 {{ISBN|1-86200-013-1}}) p78 They played a one-off international in 2001, losing to Barbados 18 points to 25. Another international was played in June 2003, where they lost 7 to 13 to the [[Cayman Islands national rugby union team|Cayman Islands]]. The Bahamas took part in the [[2007 Rugby World Cup - Americas qualification|Americas qualifying tournaments]] for the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]] in [[France]]. They won their first two matches, defeating the Cayman Islands and Bermuda, but lost their third against Jamaica. However, they did finish at the top of the Northern Pool, clinching the play-off match against the winner of the other pool. The Bahamas lost to Barbados in the play-off match, 52-3. ==World Cup record== * 1987 - Did not enter * 1991 - Did not enter * 1995 - Did not enter * 1999 - Did not qualify * 2003 - Did not qualify * 2007 - Did not qualify * 2011 - Did not qualify * 2015 - Did not qualify ==Squad== '''Squad to 2012 [[North America Caribbean Rugby Association|NACRA]] Championship''' 26 May 2012 http://www.rugbyworldcup.com/home/matches/match=12592/index.html {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120917091957/http://www.rugbyworldcup.com/home/matches/match%3D12592/index.html |date=2012-09-17 }} {| class="toccolours" style="border-collapse: collapse;" |- |valign="top"| '''Squad''' *Craig Anthony *Charles Smith *Manny Roussos *John Gates *Marcus Cheetham *Justin Cunningham *Shawn Kemp *Devon Woodside *Kevin Salabie *Jeremico Cooper (c) *Michael Watkins *Jamie Anthony *Duran Beadle *Carlton Oliver *Jamaal Curry |width="33"|  |valign="top"| '''Substitutes''' *Garfield Morrison *Earl Thurston *Bovair Davis *Casey Charlton *Dorian Butler *Giovanni Johnson *Levar Boyd '''Coach''' *Ken Hutton |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070310232151/http://www.irb.com/en/Home/MemberUnionHomePage?UnionID=37 Bahamas] on IRB.com * [http://www.rugbybahamas.com/ Rugby Bahamas] * [http://rugbydata.com/bahamas Bahamas] on rugbydata.com * http://www.americasrugbynews.com/2017/06/04/bahamas-back-life-big-win-dominican-republic/ {{National sports teams of the Bahamas}} {{National rugby teams}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bahamas National Rugby Union Team}} [[Category:Caribbean national rugby union teams]] [[Category:Rugby union in the Bahamas]] [[Category:National sports teams of the Bahamas|Rugby Union]] {{Bahamas-sport-stub}}

{{redirect|Basketball Arena|the arena in London|Basketball Arena (London)}} [[File:Game 3 of the 2006 NBA Finals.jpg|thumb|right|The home court of the [[Miami Heat]] of the [[National Basketball Association]]]] In [[basketball]], the '''basketball court''' is the playing surface, consisting of a rectangular floor with baskets at either end. In professional or organized basketball, especially when played indoors, it is usually made out of a [[wood]], often [[maple]], and highly polished and completed with a 10 foot rim. Outdoor surfaces are generally made from standard paving materials such as [[concrete]] or [[asphalt concrete|asphalt]]. == Dimensions == Basketball courts come in different sizes. In the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA), the court is {{convert|94|by|50|ft|m|sigfig=3}}. Under [[FIBA|International Basketball Federation]] (FIBA) rules,{{cite web | year = 2006 | url = http://www.fiba.com/asp_includes/download.asp?file_id=328 | title = Official Basketball Rules 2006 | format = pdf | work = | publisher = [[FIBA|International Basketball Federation]] | accessdate = 2007-04-14| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070406072645/http://www.fiba.com/asp_includes/download.asp?file_id=328| archivedate= 6 April 2007 | deadurl= no}} the court is minutely smaller, measuring exactly {{convert|28|by|15|meters|ft|sigfig=3}}. In amateur basketball, court sizes vary widely. The baskets are always {{convert|10|ft|m|sigfig=3}} above the floor (except possibly in youth competition). Basketball courts have a three-point arc at both baskets. A basket made from behind this arc is worth three points; a basket made from within this line, or with a player's foot touching the line, is worth 2 points. The free-throw line, where one stands while taking a foul shot, is located within the three-point arc at 15 feet from the basket. A foul shot is worth 1 point, but if a shot is made from the foul line while in play it is still worth 2 points.{{cite book|last=Wissel|first=Hal|title=Basketball: steps to success|year=1994|publisher=Human Kinetics Publishers, Inc.|location=United States|isbn=0-7360-5500-2|pages=ix}} ===Diagrams=== Image:Basketball courts.svg|Composite diagram of a basketball court with [[International Basketball Federation|FIBA]] (top half only), [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] (both halves), and [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] (men’s & women’s – bottom half only) markings Image:Basketball backboard and basket.svg|The backboard and basket ===Table=== {|class=wikitable |- !colspan=2 rowspan=2|Area !!colspan=2|NBA !!colspan=2| FIBA !!colspan=2|WNBA !!colspan=2| NCAA{{cite web|year=2018 |url=https://www.ncaa.org/sites/default/files/2017MBBWBB_NCAA_Basketball_Court_Diagram_20170622.pdf|title=NCAA Basketball Court Diagram|format=pdf |work= |publisher= NCAA |accessdate=March 11, 2018}} |- !Imperial !! Metric !!Imperial !! Metric !!Imperial !! Metric !!Imperial !! Metric |- |colspan=2|Court length || 94 ft || 28.65 m || 91.86 ft || 28 m ||colspan=4|''Same as NBA'' |- |colspan=2|Court width || 50 ft || 15.24 m || 49.21 ft || 15 m ||colspan=4|''Same as NBA'' |- |colspan=2|Rim height || 10 ft || 3.05 m ||colspan=6|''Same as NBA '' |- |colspan=2|Restricted arc radius || 4 ft || 1.22 m || 4.10 ft || 1.25 m ||colspan=4 | ''Same as NBA'' |- |colspan=2|Center circle diameter || 12 ft || 3.66 m || 11.81 ft || 3.6 m ||colspan=4|''Same as NBA'' |- |colspan=2|3-point line distance from the basket || 23.75 ft
22 ft in corner* || 7.24 m
6.70 m in corner* || 22.15 ft
21.65 ft in corner† || 6.75 m
6.60 m in corner† ||colspan=2|''Same as FIBA '' || 20.75 ft || 6.32 m |- |colspan=2|Key (shaded lane or
restricted area) width || 16 ft || 4.88 m || 16.08 ft || 4.9 m ||colspan=2|''Same as NBA''|| 12 ft || 3.66 m |- |colspan=2|Free-throw line distance from point on the floor directly below the backboard || 15 ft || 4.57 m || 15.09 ft || 4.6 m ||colspan=4|''Same as NBA'' |}* The NBA three-point line is 3 ft (0.91 m) from the sideline in a zone starting at the baseline and ending when it crosses the 23.75 ft (7.24 m) arc. The 22 ft (6.70 m) distance exists only at the points on the three-point line that are directly to the left and right of the basket center. † The FIBA three-point line is 2.95 ft (0.90 m) from the sideline in a zone starting at the baseline and ending when it crosses the 22.1 ft (6.75 m) arc. The 21.65 ft (6.60 m) distance exists only at the points on the three-point line that are directly to the left and right of the basket center. ==Sections== [[File:Basketball terms.png|thumb|300px|Most important terms related to the basketball court]] ===Center circle=== The only two players permitted to enter this area prior to the tipoff are the players contesting the jump ball (usually but not always centers). Both players jump when the referee throws the ball in the air, each attempting to tap the ball into the hands of a player of their own team. ===Three-point line=== The three-point line is the line that separates the two-point area from the [[three-point field goal|three-point area]]; any shot converted beyond this line counts as three points. If the shooting player steps on the line, it is counted as two points. Any foul made in the act of shooting beyond the three-point line would give the player three [[free throws]] if the shot does not go in, and one if it does. The distance to the [[three-point field goal|three-point]] line from the center of the basket varies depending on the level or league, and has changed several times. These are the current distances, with the league or level using each distance: * 19.75 ft (6.02 m): High School * 20.75 ft (6.32 m): NCAA * 21.65 ft (6.60 m) to 22.15 ft (6.75 m): WNBA and FIBA * 22 ft (6.71 m) to 23.75 ft (7.24 m): NBA The NBA adopted the three-point line at the start of the [[1979–80 NBA season|1979–80 season]]. This is of variable distance, ranging from {{convert|22|ft|m}} in the corners to {{convert|23.75|ft|m}} behind the top of the key. During the 1994–95, 1995–96 and 1996–97 seasons, the NBA attempted to address decreased scoring by shortening the overall distance of the line to a uniform {{convert|22|ft|m}} around the basket. It was moved back to its original distance after the 1996–97 season. FIBA and the NCAA both adopted the three-point line in 1985. In most high school associations in the United States, the distance is 19.75 feet. This was formerly the distance for [[college basketball]] as well. On May 26, 2007, the NCAA playing rules committee agreed to move the three-point line back one foot to 20.75 feet for the men. This rule went into effect for the 2008–2009 season. The three-point line for women (NCAA) moved back one foot to 20.75 feet at the start of the 2011–2012 season. The international distance, used in most countries outside the United States and in [[FIBA]] and [[WNBA]] competition, is currently 6.6 m (21.65 ft) to 6.75 m (22.15 ft). ===Perimeter=== The perimeter is defined as the areas outside the free throw lane and inside the three-point line. Shots converted (successfully made) from this area are called "perimeter shots" or "medium-range shots." If a player's foot is on the three-point line, the shot is considered a perimeter shot. ===Low post area=== The low post is defined as the areas that are closest to the basket but outside of the free throw lane.[http://nbaballers.org/BasketballGlossary/Basketball-Glossary-L.html Basketball Glossary Terms, Definition, Lane violation, Low post] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430102709/http://nbaballers.org/BasketballGlossary/Basketball-Glossary-L.html |date=April 30, 2009 }} This area is fundamental to strategy in basketball. Skilled low post players can score many points per game without ever taking a [[Jump shot (basketball)|jump shot]]. === Key === The [[key (basketball)|key]], free throw lane or shaded lane refers to the usually painted area beneath the basket; for the NBA it is {{convert|16|ft|m}} wide, for the NCAA it is {{convert|12|ft|m}} wide; for both instances it extends {{convert|15|ft|m}} from the backboard. At the top of the rectangle is the [[free throw]] line, behind which players shoot uncontested shots when they're fouled. A circle is drawn around the free-throw line with a {{convert|6|ft|m}} [[radius]]; this is used for jump ball instances, as is done at the [[#Center circle|center circle]]. Two 6-inch hash lines, 3 ft from the free throw lane line and 5 ft 8 in from the free throw line, show the lower defensive box linked to the restricted area. For FIBA tournaments, since October 2010 the key has been a rectangle 4.9 m wide and 5.8 m long. Previously it was a trapezoid 3.7 meters (12 ft) wide at the free-throw line and 6 meters (19 feet and 6.25 inches) at the end line. The key is primarily used to prevent players from staying beneath the basket of the opponents' team for long periods (maximum three seconds). The restricted area arc is a semi-circular arc drawn around the area directly underneath the basket. With some exceptions, members of the defending team cannot draw charging fouls in this area. The restricted arc in all North American rule sets above high school level ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] men's and women's, [[National Basketball Association|NBA]], and [[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]]) has a radius 4 feet (1.22 m) from below the center of the basket. The restricted area arc rule first appeared at any level of basketball in the NBA in the 1997-98 season.{{cite web |url=http://factuation.com/shaq-and-the-no-charge-zone-rule/ |title=Shaq and the No Charge Zone Rule |publisher=Factuation |date=July 1, 2015 |website=Factuation |access-date=February 27, 2018 |quote=In the 1997-1998 season, NBA added the “no charge zone” or the “restricted area”. This is the portion of the key, denoted by an arc in the painted area that is positioned four feet from the basket. The arc is important because a defending player can not force a charging foul within this area. It was designed to provide benefit offensive post-up player like [Shaquille] O’Neal, players who drive to the basket and limit collisions.}} The NCAA restricted area arc was originally established for the 2011–12 men's and women's seasons at a {{conv|3|ft|adj=on}} radius from below the center of the basket, and was extended to match the (W)NBA radius for the 2015–16 season and beyond. ===Other lines=== On NBA floors, two hash marks are drawn at the end lines near the key to mark the area known as the lower defensive box. A defensive player is allowed to draw a charging foul within the restricted arc if the offensive player receives the ball and/or starts his drive within this area.http://www.nba.com/nba101/misunderstood_0708.html Also, two lines are drawn on each of the sidelines, 28 feet from each of the endlines, which designates the extent of the coaching box and bench. This line marks the farthest extent a coach (aside from the sidelines) can stand. Directly behind this area is the team bench. On the half-court line of NBA floors two lines extend outside the playing court, designating the place where substitutes wait before they can enter the playing court; directly behind this area are the various off-court officials such as the timekeeper and reserve referee. ===FIBA changes=== On April 26, 2008, FIBA announced several major rules changes involving the court markings. These changes took effect for major international competitions on October 1, 2010, after that year's World Championships [[2010 FIBA World Championship|for men]] and [[2010 FIBA World Championship for Women|women]], and became mandatory for other competitions on October 1, 2012 (although national federations could adopt the new markings before 2012). The changes were as follows.{{cite press release|url=http://www.fiba.com/pages/eng/fc/news/lateNews/p/newsid/24352/arti.html |title=The FIBA Central Board approves historic rule changes |publisher=FIBA |date=2008-04-26 |accessdate=2008-04-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080430210952/http://www.fiba.com/pages/eng/fc/news/lateNews/p/newsid/24352/arti.html| archivedate= 30 April 2008 | deadurl= no}} * The shape of the key changed from a trapezoid to a rectangle as it is in the NBA, with NBA dimensions. * The three-point line moved back to 6.75 meters (22 ft 1.7 in) from 6.25 meters (20 ft 6.1 in), compared to {{convert|23|ft|9|in|m|abbr=on}} for the NBA at the top of the arc. * The FIBA adopted the NBA's restricted area arc with a marginally wider radius of 1.25 meters (4 ft 1.2 in). ==See also== *[[List of indoor arenas in the United States#Major college indoor arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Basketball courts}} * [http://www.free-power-point-templates.com/articles/free-basketball-court-powerpoint-template/ Free Basketball Court Layout Template] *{{cite web|publisher=[[International Basketball Federation]]| author=FIBA Central Board| title=Official Basketball Rules 2010: Basketball Equipment| date=2010-04-17| accessdate=2010-07-15| url=http://www.fiba.com/pages/mod/v3/util/downMana.asp?fileID=1258| format=pdf}} {{basketball}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Basketball Court}} [[Category:Basketball terminology|Court]] [[Category:Rules of basketball|Court]] [[Category:Sports rules and regulations]] [[Category:Sports venues by type]] [[Category:Playing field surfaces]] [[Category:Basketball equipment]]

Summer Olympics}} Cape Verdean athletes have so far achieved qualifying standards in the following athletics events (up to a maximum of 3 athletes in each event at the 'A' Standard, and 1 at the 'B' Standard).{{cite web|title=iaaf.org – Top Lists|url=http://www.iaaf.org/statistics/toplists/index.html|publisher=IAAF|accessdate=June 4, 2011}}{{cite web|title=IAAF Games of the XXX Olympiad – Athens 2004 Entry Standards|url=http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/olympic-games-athens|publisher=[[IAAF]]|accessdate=4 June 2011}} ;Key *'''Note'''–Ranks given for track events are within the athlete's heat only *'''Q''' = Qualified for the next round *'''q''' = Qualified for the next round as a fastest loser ''or'', in field events, by position without achieving the qualifying target *'''NR''' = National They currently compete in the Americas Zone Group II. ==History== Chile competed in its first Fed Cup in [[1968 Federation Cup (tennis)|1968]]. revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Dunc Gray Velodrome | nickname = | image = 1Dunc Gray Velodrome.jpg | image_size = 350px | location = Carysfield Rd, [[Bass Hill, New South Wales]] | coordinates = {{coord|33|54|27|S|150|59|55|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = May 1998 | opened = 26 January 2000 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Baltic Pine | construction_cost = [[Australian dollar|A$]]42m | architect = Ron Webb (track) | former_names = | tenants = | seating_capacity = 3,150 |}}
The '''Dunc Gray Velodrome''' is an Australian velodrome located at [[Bass Hill]] approximately 5 kilometres north west of the [[Sydney]] suburb of [[Bankstown, New South Wales|Bankstown]]. The cycling venue for the 2000 Olympic games, the Dunc Gray Velodrome was opened on 28 November 1999 and is named after [[Edgar "Dunc" Gray]], the first Australian to win a cycling Gold Medal at the [[Olympic Games]] ([[1932 Summer Olympics|Los Angeles 1932]]).<ref name="Beech">{{cite news | url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/south-west/sydney-olympics-future-plans-for-dunc-gray-velodrome-15-years-after-olympics/news-story/9a90bd2c419e0d8ff42cb30733f11dd2 | title=Sydney Olympics: Future plans for Dunc Gray Velodrome 15 years after Olympics | work=Canterbury-Bankstown Express | author=James Beech | date=2015-08-11 | accessdate=2016-06-25}}</ref>
At the time of its construction, the State Government owned the velodrome. Bankstown Council managed the velodrome under a sublease. In 1998, the council sublet the velodrome to Bankstown Sports Club, under a 21-year sublease. The council is scheduled to resume control of the velodrome in 2019.<ref name="Beech"/>
==Construction== Costing $42 million as a [[Cycling at the 2000 Summer Olympics|track cycling]] venue for the [[2000 Summer Olympics|Sydney 2000 Olympics]],<ref>[http://library.la84.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2000/2000v1.pdf 2000 ''Official Report of the XXVII Summer Olympiad. Volume One - Preparing for the Games''. Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (2001), p. 373.]</ref> construction of the velodrome, as well as an 800m Criterium Practice Track, commenced in May 1998 and finished in November 1999. It currently has a [[seating capacity]] of 3,150, but was expanded to 5,821 seats to cater for the 2000 Olympics.
At 250 metres length, 60 kilometres worth of Baltic Pine (Finland) were used in its composition. The track bends at a maximum angle of 42° degrees, while the straights are at 12.5°. The Safety Track is 5 metres wide and the racing surface is of 7 metres width.
==Events== The first major international cycling event ever held was the Oceania International Cycling Grand Prix from 8 to 12 December 1999 – an official pre-Olympic test event.
In April 2000 it hosted the 'Bankstown Millennium Buzz' performance in celebrating the Olympics and the millennium year. It hosted six days of track cycling events at the [[2000 Summer Olympics]], as well as Paralympic cycling.
In October 2007, The Dunc Gray Velodrome hosted the 2007 UCI Track Cycling Masters World Championships, for riders 30+ years of age.
[[File:Dunc Gray Veledrom in Bass Hill New South Wales.jpg|thumb|left|600px|The Dunc Gray Velodrome]] {{clear}}
==See also== {{Portal|City of Bankstown|Cycling}} * [[2000 Summer Olympics venues]] * [[Cycling in Sydney]]

[[Lakewood Township, New Jersey|Lakewood, NJ]] 08701 | coordinates = {{coord|40|4|31|N|74|11|12|W|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = April 17, 2000{{cite news |title=Lakewood Builds It; Hopes Fans Will Come|first=Wilford S.|last=Shamlin|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/app/access/1845111771.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+18%2C+2000&author=WILFORD+S+SHAMLIN&pub=Asbury+Park+Press&desc=Lakewood+builds+it%3B+hopes+fans+will+come&pqatl=google|newspaper=[[Asbury Park Press]]|date=April 18, 2000|accessdate=September 16, 2011}} | opened = April 6, 2001{{cite news |title=Claws' Comeback Falls Short|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/app/access/1842248081.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+07%2C+2001&author=&pub=Asbury+Park+Press&desc=Claws'+comeback+falls+short&pqatl=google|newspaper=[[Asbury Park Press]]|date=April 7, 2001|accessdate=September 16, 2011}} | owner = Lakewood Development Corporation | operator = Lakewood Development Corporation{{cite news |title=Coming Attractions|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2000/05/20000508/No-Topic-Name/COMING-ATTRACTIONS.aspx|work=SportsBusiness Journal|date=May 8, 2000|accessdate=September 14, 2011}} | surface = Grass | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]20 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|20000000|2003}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[HNTB]] | services engineer = Henderson Engineers, Inc.{{cite web |title=Sports/Recreation|url=http://www.hei-eng.com/Portfolio/SportsRecreation|publisher=Henderson Engineers, Inc|accessdate=March 8, 2014}} | project_manager = [[Hill International]]{{cite web |title=Sports Facilities|url=http://www.hillintl.com/?fa=market&marketSidebarId=52&show=fp|publisher=Hill International|accessdate=March 8, 2014}} | general_contractor = Epic Group, Inc.{{cite web |title=GPU Energy Park|url=http://www.epicbuilds.com/entertainment/GPU%20Energy/GPU.htm|publisher=Epic Group, Inc.|accessdate=March 8, 2014}} | tenants = [[Lakewood BlueClaws]] ([[South Atlantic League|SAL]]) (2002–present) | seating_capacity = 8,000 | dimensions = Left: {{convert|325|ft|m}}
Center: {{convert|400|ft|m}}
Right: {{convert|325|ft|m}} }} '''FirstEnergy Park''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Lakewood Township, New Jersey|Lakewood Township]], [[New Jersey]]. It is primarily used for [[baseball]] and is the home field of the [[Lakewood BlueClaws]] single A [[minor league]] baseball team, affiliated with the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] [[Major League Baseball]] team. It is also used for outdoor concerts, featuring touring musical artists such as [[Bob Dylan]]. It was built in 2001 and has 6,588 seats and seats 8,000 with berm seating.{{cite web |title=BlueClaws Cap Crowds at 8,000|url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20120305&content_id=27030780&vkey=news_t427&fext=.jsp&sid=t427|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=March 5, 2012|accessdate=August 11, 2013}} ==History== The team attendance record is 13,003, set on August 26, 2002.{{cite news |title=Claws Close a Banner Year|first=Dan|last=Cichalski|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/app/doc/437518715.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+27%2C+2002&author=CICHALSKI%2C+DAN&pub=Asbury+Park+Press&edition=&startpage=&desc=CLAWS+CLOSE+A+BANNER+YEAR+13%2C003+fans+cram+seats%2C+lawn%2C+for+home+finale+-+a+3-0+win|publisher=[[Asbury Park Press]]|date=February 28, 2002|accessdate=May 30, 2014|page=A1}} FirstEnergy Park has held 13 crowds over 9,000 and 81 crowds over 8,000 in just eight years of play. FirstEnergy Park was featured in ''[[Baseball America]]'''s 2009 ''Great Parks'' calendar. It was the second time that the home of the Lakewood BlueClaws was highlighted in the calendar.{{cite web |title=At Home With the BlueClaws|first=Benjamin|last=Hill|url=http://web.minorleaguebaseball.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20090211&content_id=508111&vkey=news_milb&fext=.jsp|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=February 12, 2009|accessdate=June 10, 2010}} ==Features== The ballpark features two general admission, grass seating areas, one in left field and another in right, 20 luxury suites, two party decks, three picnic areas, and a full video scoreboard, with a 23' x 23' video board that can play over 4.4 trillion shades of color in high definition.{{cite web |title=FirstEnergy Park Lakewood, New Jersey|first=Brian|last=Merzbach|url=http://www.ballparkreviews.com/lakewood/lakewood.htm|work=Ballpark Reviews|accessdate=March 8, 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?sid=t427&ymd=20100218&content_id=8089998&vkey=team1 Lakewood BlueClaws: FirstEnergy Park] *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2002/Lakewood/Lakewood.htm FirstEnergy Park Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] *[http://www.lakewoodnj.gov/parks_detail.php Parks: Township of Lakewood, NJ] {{SAL ballparks}} [[Category:Baseball venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Lakewood Township, New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues in the New York metropolitan area]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Ocean County, New Jersey]] [[Category:2001 establishments in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2001]]

revision.comment: Gaawiki moved page [[GAA Scores]] to [[GAA Scores Podcast]]: Changed to correct name
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2015}} {{Unreferenced|date=February 2015}} }} {{Infobox Podcast |image = File:GAA_Scores_Logo.jpg |caption = |hosting = Conor Donnelly |language = English |rss = |atom = |rss_other = |atom_other = |updates = |length = ca. 60min |camera = |direction = |production = |picture_format = |video_format = |audio_format = MP3 |began = 2013 |ended = |genre = Sports |ratings = |cited_for = |cited_as = |provider = |url = http://www.gaascores.com/ }}
'''GAA Scores''' is a [[podcast]] and website about [[Gaelic Athletic Association|Gaelic Games]].
==History== GAA Scores was originally launched as a [[Twitter]] account by Conor Donnelly in January 2012, with updates from [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]] teams in various countries. The debut match was a [[Dr. McKenna Cup]] tie between [[Derry GAA|Derry]] and [[Ulster University#Jordanstown|UUJ]] at [[Celtic Park (Derry)|Celtic Park]]. The account received almost 1,000 followers on Twitter within the first week. Later that summer a website was founded with news and opinions on Gaelic Games.
The podcast was launched in May 2013 with Conor Donnelly, Pearse Corcoran and Michael O'Connor hosting the first season. [[Fermanagh GAA|Fermanagh]] footballer [[Ryan McCluskey]] replaced O'Connor midway through the second season.
==Podcast format== The show is released weekly through [[iTunes]] and [[SoundCloud]].
==Link up with Gaelic Life== On Thursday 12 February 2015, it was announced that GAA Scores would be linking up with [[Ulster]]-based newspaper, ''Gaelic Life'', to bring further coverage of the clubs and county within the province for the rest of the season.
==Hosts== *Conor Donnelly (2013–Present) *Pearse Corcoran (2013–Present) *[[Ryan McCluskey]] (2014–Present)
==Previous guests== *[[Pádraic Collins]] ([[Clare GAA|Clare]]) *[[Colin Walshe]] ([[Monaghan GAA|Monaghan]]) *[[Harry Kehoe]] ([[Wexford GAA|Wexford]]) *Oisin Langan ([[Newstalk]]) *Derrick Lynch ([[Clare FM]]) *Ronan Scott (Gaelic Life) *Ciaran Woods (Gaelic Life) *Niall McCoy (Gaelic Life) *Shane McCabe ([[Fermanagh GAA|Fermanagh]]) *Damian Stack *Cormac O'Malley *Conán Doherty (DerryNow.com) *Cahair O'Kane (County Derry Post) *Dan Bannon (LouthAndProud.com) *Ger McCarthy ([[Irish Examiner]]) *Daragh O’Conchuír *Emmet Ryan (action81.com) *Fintan O’Toole (the42.ie) *Daniel St Ledger ([[Carlow GAA|Carlow]])
==Awards and recognition== *Voted 5th in the Irish Examiner’s "Top 50 Essential GAA Tweeters" (May 2012) *SportsNewsIRELAND’s "Top 30 GAA Twitter Accounts to follow" (August 2012) *Final 10 in the RaboTweeties Award for the "best use of Twitter by an Irish owner" (September 2013) *Semi Finalists in the Bord Gáis Social Media Awards for "Most Innovative and Effective Use of Social Media in Ireland" (May 2014) *Finalist in Blog Awards Ireland for "Best Sport & Recreation Blog" (October 2014) *Semi Finalist in the Web Awards for "Best Sports Site" (October 2014) *Winner of "Best Sports Twitter Account in Ireland" in the RaboTweeties Awards (November 2014)

==June 30, 2004== *[[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: In the first semi-final [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] beat the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] 2–1. This is the first time Portugal have reached the final of a major football tournament. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3844461.stm (BBC)] *[[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] quarter-finals: ** Defending champion [[Serena Williams]] defeats fellow American [[Jennifer Capriati]], 6–1, 6–1. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tennis/wimbledon04/news/story?id=1831915 (ESPN)] ** Fourth seed [[Amélie Mauresmo]] (France) defeats [[Paola Suárez]] ([[Argentina]]) 6–0 5–7 6–1. [http://www.reuters.co.uk/newsArticle.jhtml?type=tennisNews&storyID=5554791&section=news (Reuters)] ** Unseeded [[Croatia]]n [[Mario Ančić]] beats the fifth seed, Britain's [[Tim Henman]], 7–6 (7–5) 6–4 6–2. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tennis/3853481.stm (BBC)] ** Second seed [[Andy Roddick]] (USA) beats [[Sjeng Schalken]] (Netherlands) 7–6 (7–4) 7–6 (11–9) 6–3. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tennis/3854635.stm (BBC)] ** Defending champion [[Roger Federer]] (Switzerland) beats [[Lleyton Hewitt]] (Australia) 6–1 6–7 (1–7) 6–0 6–4. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tennis/3854959.stm (BBC)] ** Tenth seed [[Sébastien Grosjean]] (France) defeats [[Florian Mayer]] (Germany) 7–5 6–4 6–2. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tennis/3855153.stm (BBC)] *[[Indy Racing League|IRL]]: Two-time [[Indianapolis 500]] winner [[Al Unser, Jr.]] announces his retirement from racing after over twenty years racing in [[Champ Car|CART]] and the IRL. [http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1831653 (ESPN)] *[[NASCAR]]: [[Tony Stewart]] was fined [[United States dollar|US]] $50,000 by NASCAR for an altercation with [[Brian Vickers]] following Sunday's [[Dodge/Save Mart 350]]. He was also docked 25 championship points, dropping him to sixth in the [[Nextel Cup]] Championship points race. NASCAR stopped short of suspending Stewart for a race, which would likely have eliminated him from the points race altogether. [http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1832141 (ESPN)] *[[Major League Baseball|MLB]]: [[Colorado Rockies]] hitter [[Larry Walker]] gets his 2,000th hit in a 5–4 loss against the [[Milwaukee Brewers]]. Walker is the 234th player to reach the milestone. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=1832424 (ESPN)]
==June 29, 2004== *[[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] quarter-finals: ** Fifth seed [[Lindsay Davenport]] (USA) beats unseeded [[Karolina Šprem]] ([[Croatia]]) 6–2 6–2. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tennis/3850757.stm (BBC)] ** [[Maria Sharapova]] (Russia), seeded 13, beats [[Ai Sugayama]] (Japan), seeded 11, 5–7 7–5 6–1. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tennis/3850649.stm (BBC)] *[[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]: [[Tim Henman]] advances into the quarter-finals with a win over Australian [[Mark Philippoussis]], last year's runner-up, 6–2 7–5 6–7(3) 7–6(5). [http://www.tennis-x.com/story/2004-06-29/h.php (TennisX)] *[[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: The [[Orlando Magic]] trade star [[Tracy McGrady]] to the [[Houston Rockets]] along with [[Cuttino Mobley]] and [[Kelvin Cato]] for [[Steve Francis]], [[Juwan Howard]], [[Tyronn Lue]] and [[Reece Gaines]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=1831594 (ESPN)] *[[Major League Baseball|MLB]]: [[Arizona Diamondbacks]] pitcher [[Randy Johnson]] throws his 4,000th [[strikeout]], joining [[Nolan Ryan]], [[Roger Clemens]] and [[Steve Carlton]] at that milestone. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=1831803 (ESPN)]
==June 28, 2004== * Pakistan's top amateur [[boxing]] prospect, [[Maurin Karim]], is banned from the [[Olympic Games]] for testing positive for a banned substance during a previous competition.
==June 27, 2004== * [[Cricket]]: [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] defeat [[England cricket team|England]] by 7 wickets in a [[One Day International]] at [[Trent Bridge]], [[Nottingham]] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: In the last quarterfinal, the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] defeats [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] 3–0. The Czechs blew open a game which had been scoreless at halftime with a goal by [[Jan Koller]] and two by [[Milan Baroš]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/euro_2004/3830623.stm (BBC)] * [[2004 College World Series|College World Series]]: [[California State University, Fullerton|Cal State Fullerton]] wins the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[baseball]] [[College World Series]], defeating [[University of Texas at Austin|Texas]] 3–2 to win the best-of-three championship series 2–0. [http://sports.espn.go.com/minorlbb/cws/recap?date=20040627&key=20040627CWSCSFULLRTONTEXAS&gamenum=0 (ESPN)] * [[Arena Football League]]: The [[San Jose SaberCats]] defeat the [[Arizona Rattlers]], 69–62, to win [[ArenaBowl]] XVIII. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/news/story?id=1830576 (ESPN)] * [[NASCAR]]: [[Jeff Gordon]] wins the [[Dodge/Save Mart 350]] at [[Infineon Raceway]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1830556 (ESPN)] * [[PGA Tour]]: Australian [[Adam Scott (golfer)|Adam Scott]] wins the [[Booz Allen Classic]] at [[TPC at Avenel]], shooting a final round 68 to finish at 21-under par for the tournament. [http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/news/story?id=1830493 (ESPN)] * [[Golf]]: [[Ya-Ni Tseng]] of [[Chinese Taipei]] ([[Taiwan]]) came back from four holes down to upset defending champion [[Michelle Wie]] at the [[U.S. Women's Amateur Public Links]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/news/story?id=1830439 (ESPN)] * [[Gymnastics|United States Gymnastics Olympic trials]]: [[Courtney Kupets]] and [[Courtney McCool]] finish the competition in first and second place, respectively. Other top-ten finishers include [[Carly Patterson]] (#3), [[Tasha Schwiker]] (#7) and [[Carly Janiga]] (#9).[http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/news/story?id=1830589 (ESPN)] * [[Baseball]]: [[Carlos Peña]] hits a grand slam [[home run]] with two outs and two strikes in the bottom of the ninth inning, as the [[Detroit Tigers]] defeat the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]], 9 to 5.[http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameId=240627106 (ESPN)] * [[Drag racing]]: [[NHRA]] driver [[Darrell Russell (drag racer)|Darrell Russell]] dies of injuries sustained during an accident at the Sears Craftsman Nationals at [[Madison, Illinois]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1830632 (ESPN)] * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]: On [[People's Sunday]], [[England|Englishman]] [[Tim Henman]] advances to the third round by defeating [[Hicham Arazi]] 7–6 (6), 6–4, 3–6, 6–2. Amongst the others advancing are [[Andy Roddick]], [[Jennifer Capriati]], defending women's champion [[Serena Williams]] and defending men's champion [[Roger Federer]].[https://news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/ap/20040628/ap_on_sp_te_ga_su/ten_wimbledon_130 (AP via Yahoo! news)] * [[Gymnastics|United States Gymnastics Olympic trials]]: [[Courtney Kupets]] and [[Courtney McCool]] finish the competition in first and second place, respectively. Other top-ten finishers include [[Carly Patterson]] (#3), [[Tasha Schwiker]] (#7) and [[Carly Janiga]] (#9). [http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/news/story?id=1830589 (ESPN)] * [[Baseball]]: [[Carlos Peña]] hits a grand slam home run with two outs and two strikes in the bottom of the ninth inning, as the [[Detroit Tigers]] defeat the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]], 9 to 5. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameId=240627106 (ESPN)]
==June 26, 2004== * [[Rugby union]]: ** the [[Wallabies Rugby Team|Wallabies]] (Australia) defeat [[England national rugby union team|England]] 51–15 at [[Suncorp Stadium]] in [[Brisbane]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/international/3838221.stm (BBC)] ** the [[All Blacks]] (New Zealand) defeat the [[Pumas Rugby Team|Pumas]] ([[Argentina]]) 41–7 at [[Waikato Stadium]] in [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/international/3838953.stm (BBC)] ** the [[Springbok Rugby Team|Springboks]] (South Africa) defeat [[Wales]] 53–18 at [[Securicor Loftus]] in [[Pretoria]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/rugby_union/international/3837479.stm (BBC)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: In the third quarter-final, the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] beat [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] 5–4 on penalties. The match ended 0–0 after extra time. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3831335.stm (BBC)] * [[National Hockey League|NHL Draft]]: With the first pick in the 2004 NHL draft, the [[Washington Capitals]] select [[Alexander Ovechkin]] from Russia, the second Russian to go first in the draft in NHL history. ([[Ilya Kovalchuk]] of the [[Atlanta Thrashers]] was drafted first in 2001.) [[Yevgeny Malkin]] was selected second by the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] and [[Cam Barker]] from Canada was selected third by the [[Chicago Blackhawks]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/draft2004/news/story?id=1829872 (ESPN)] * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]: Rain washed out play for the second day in a week. For only the third time in Wimbledon's history, matches will be played on Sunday to try to catch up. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tennis/3841475.stm (BBC)] * [[2004 College World Series|College World Series]]: [[California State University, Fullerton|Cal State, Fullerton]] defeats [[University of Texas at Austin|Texas]], 6–4, in the first game of the best of three championship series. [http://sports.espn.go.com/minorlbb/cws/recap?key=20040626CWSTEXASCSFULLRTON (ESPN)] * [[Indy Racing League|IRL]]: [[Dan Wheldon]] wins the [[SunTrust Indy Challenge]] at [[Richmond International Raceway]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1830145 (ESPN)]
==June 25, 2004== * [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: [[Colorado]] District Judge [[Terry Ruckriegle]] set the starting date of the [[sexual assault]] trial of NBA star [[Kobe Bryant]] for August 27. On that date, prospective jurors will be questioned. The trial, to be held in [[Eagle, Colorado]], is expected to last three to four weeks. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=1829559 (ESPN)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: In the second quarter-final, unfancied [[Greece national football team|Greece]] surprisingly beat strong favourites [[France national football team|France]] 1–0. Until this tournament Greece had never won a match in European Championships or World Cup finals tournaments. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3830563.stm (BBC)] * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]: Second seed and [[French Open]] champion [[Anastasia Myskina]] is upset by American [[Amy Frazier]] in the second round, 4–6, 6–4, 6–4. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tennis/wimbledon04/news/story?id=1829413 (ESPN)]
==June 24, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: In the first quarter-final, [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] beat [[England national football team|England]] 6–5 on penalties after the two teams drew 2–2 after extra time. The referee [[Urs Meier]] controversially disallowed a goal by England in the last minute of normal time. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3830443.stm (BBC)] * [[2004 NBA Draft|NBA Draft]]: [[Dwight Howard]] from [[Southwest Atlanta Christian Academy]] is selected in the first pick of the draft by the [[Orlando Magic]]. [[Emeka Okafor]] of the [[University of Connecticut]] is selected by the [[Charlotte Bobcats]] with the second pick. [[Ben Gordon (basketball)|Ben Gordon]], also from Connecticut, is selected third by the [[Chicago Bulls]]. [[Shaun Livingston]] from [[Peoria Central High School]] is selected fourth by the [[Los Angeles Clippers]]. [[Devin Harris]] from the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison|University of Wisconsin]] was selected fifth by the [[Washington Wizards]], but is, in actuality, part of the trade made Wednesday with the [[Dallas Mavericks]]. * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]: Third seed [[Venus Williams]] is upset in the second round of play by [[Karolina Šprem]], 7–6 (5), 7–6 (6). The match was marred by a chair umpire's scoring error in the second-set tiebreaker that incorrectly gave Šprem a point. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tennis/wimbledon04/news/story?id=1827410 (ESPN)] * [[Major League Baseball|MLB]]: [[Kansas City Royals]] star [[Carlos Beltrán]] is traded to the [[Houston Astros]] in a three-team deal. The [[Oakland Athletics]] receive reliever [[Octavio Dotel]] from Houston and the Royals receive some prospects from both teams. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=1828880 (ESPN)] * [[Barry Bonds]] lashes out in public at sprinter [[Tim Montgomery]], after Montgomery accused him the week before of being involved with the [[BALCO]] [[steroids]] company.[http://aolsvc.news.aol.com/sports/article.adp?id=20040624172009990001 AOL] * [[National Hockey League|NHL]]: [[Vancouver Canucks]] star [[Todd Bertuzzi]] was formally charged with assault by [[Vancouver]] police after a four-month investigation stemming from a March 8 hit on the [[Colorado Avalanche]]'s [[Steve Moore (ice hockey)|Steve Moore]] that left him with three fractured vertebrae, post-concussion symptoms and amnesia. Bertuzzi had been previously suspended without pay by the NHL for the final 13 games of the past season and the entire playoffs for the incident. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=1827388 (ESPN)] * [[2004 College World Series|College World Series]]: [[California State University, Fullerton|Cal State, Fullerton]] advances to the College World Series finals, defeating [[University of South Carolina Columbia|South Carolina]], 4–0. [http://sports.espn.go.com/minorlbb/cws/recap?key=20040624CWS (ESPN)]
==June 23, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group D – In the final group matches, [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]], which had already qualified for the quarterfinals as group winners, beat [[Germany national football team|Germany]] 2–1, and [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] beat [[Latvia national football team|Latvia]] 3–0. The Netherlands qualifies for the quarterfinals as group runners-up. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/euro_2004/3787551.stm (BBC)] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/euro_2004/3787547.stm (BBC)] * [[2004 College World Series|College World Series]]: ** [[University of Texas at Austin|Texas]] eliminates [[University of Georgia|Georgia]] from competition, 7–6, and secures itself a place in the College World Series finals. ** [[University of South Carolina Columbia|South Carolina]] defeated [[California State University, Fullerton|Cal State Fullerton]] 5–3 to force a rematch between the two teams on Thursday to determine which team will play in the College World Series finals. * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]: The matches are suspended due to rain. * [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: The [[Dallas Mavericks]] trade [[Antawn Jamison]], the 2003–2004 [[NBA Sixth Man of the Year Award]] winner, to the [[Washington Wizards]] for [[Jerry Stackhouse]], [[Christian Laettner]] and the Wizards' first-round draft pick (fifth pick overall). It is thought that the Mavericks, who have reportedly been attempting to establish a trade with the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] for star center [[Shaquille O'Neal]], made the trade as a possible means to sweeten any potential trade with the Lakers. The trade was officially consummated at the [[2004 NBA Draft|NBA Draft]] the next day. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=1827125 (ESPN)]
==June 22, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group C – In the final group matches, [[Italy national football team|Italy]] beat [[Bulgaria national football team|Bulgaria]] 2–1, and [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] and [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] draw 2–2. Sweden qualify for the quarter-finals as group winners; Denmark as group runners-up. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787525.stm (BBC)] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787527.stm (BBC)] * [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: The expansion [[Charlotte Bobcats]] made their selections in the NBA expansion draft. While the Bobcats selected 19 players, many are restricted free agents and are expected to be used as bargaining chips in trades with other teams. Among those drafted include [[Marcus Fizer]] of the [[Chicago Bulls]], [[Jahidi White]] of the [[Phoenix Suns]], [[Gerald Wallace]] of the [[Sacramento Kings]] and [[Jason Kapono]] of the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=1826536 (ESPN)] * [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: ESPN reports indicate that the [[Orlando Magic]] have traded disgruntled star [[Tracy McGrady]] to the [[Houston Rockets]] along with [[Juwan Howard]], [[Tyronn Lue]] and [[Reece Gaines]] for the Rockets' [[Steve Francis]], [[Cuttino Mobley]] and [[Kelvin Cato]]. The trade has not yet been completely finalized because Francis cannot be officially traded until July 1 due to salary cap restrictions. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=1825839 (ESPN)] * [[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]]: [[Lisa Leslie]] of the [[Los Angeles Sparks]] has her second [[slam dunk|dunk shot]] as a professional player as the Sparks beat the [[New York Liberty]], 65–49. Leslie's two dunks are the only two dunks in WNBA history [http://wnba.com/ (WNBA)] * [[2004 College World Series|College World Series]]: ** [[University of Georgia|Georgia]] eliminates [[University of Arizona|Arizona]] from competition with a 3–1 victory. ** [[University of South Carolina Columbia|South Carolina]] eliminates [[University of Miami|Miami]] from competition with a 15–11 win.
==June 21, 2004== * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]: [[Martina Navratilova]] defeated [[Colombia]]n [[Catalina Castaño]], 6–0, 6–1 in the first round match at Wimbledon. Navratilova, 47, became the oldest player to win a singles match since the Open Era began in 1968. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tennis/wimbledon04/news/story?id=1825490 (ESPN)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group B – In the final group matches, [[France national football team|France]] beat [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] 3–1, and [[England national football team|England]] beat [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] 4–2. France qualify for the quarter-finals as group winners; England as group runners-up. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787403.stm (BBC)] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787401.stm (BBC)] * [[2004 College World Series|College World Series]]: ** [[University of South Carolina Columbia|South Carolina]] eliminates [[Louisiana State University|LSU]] from competition with a 15–4 win. ** [[California State University, Fullerton|Cal State, Fullerton]] defeats [[University of Miami|Miami]], 6–3.
==June 20, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group A – In the final group matches, [[Russia national football team|Russia]] beat [[Greece national football team|Greece]] 2–1, and [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] beat [[Spain national football team|Spain]] 1–0. Portugal qualify for the quarter-finals as group winners; Greece as group runners-up. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787399.stm (BBC)] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787397.stm (BBC)] * [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]]: [[Retief Goosen]] holds on to win his second U.S. Open (4-under par) in a round that saw no golfer shoot better than even par. [[Phil Mickelson]] was the runner-up at 2-under par. [[Jeff Maggert]] finished third, [[Mike Weir]] and [[Shigeki Maruyama]] tied for fourth. [http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/usopen04/news/story?id=1825197 (ESPN)] *[[Major League Baseball|MLB]]: [[Ken Griffey, Jr.]] becomes the 20th player to hit his 500th career [[home run]], connecting off the [[St. Louis Cardinals]]' [[Matt Morris (baseball)|Matt Morris]] in the sixth inning of a 6–0 [[Cincinnati Reds]] win. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=1825228 (ESPN)] * It is announced that [[Tiffeny Milbrett]] will no longer participate in the [[United States women's national soccer team]]. * [[NASCAR]]: [[Ryan Newman (racing driver)|Ryan Newman]] wins the [[DHL 400]] at [[Michigan International Speedway]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1825279 (ESPN)] * [[Formula One]]: [[Michael Schumacher]] wins the [[United States Grand Prix]] at the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1825209 (ESPN)] * [[Champ Car]]: [[Sébastien Bourdais]] wins the [[Grand Prix of Portland]]. * [[LPGA]]: [[Cristie Kerr]] wins the [[ShopRite LPGA Classic]] with a 3-under 68, defeating 17-year-old [[Paula Creamer]] by one stroke. [http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/news/story?id=1825270 (ESPN)] * [[2004 College World Series|College World Series]]: ** [[University of Arizona|Arizona]] eliminates [[University of Arkansas|Arkansas]] from competition with a 7–2 win. ** [[University of Texas at Austin|Texas]] defeats [[University of Georgia|Georgia]], 9–3.
==June 19, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group D – The [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] comes back from a 2–0 deficit to defeat [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] 3–2. This result, combined with the Latvia-Germany draw earlier that day, clinched the top spot in Group D for the Czechs, and makes the Czechs the first squad to qualify for the quarterfinals. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/euro_2004/3787537.stm (BBC)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group D – [[Latvia national football team|Latvia]] and [[Germany national football team|Germany]] draw 0–0. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/euro_2004/3787541.stm (BBC)] * [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]]: Playing in stiff winds, South African [[Retief Goosen]] takes a two-shot lead (at 5-under par) at the U.S. Open after shooting a 1-under 69. [[Ernie Els]] and [[Phil Mickelson]] are tied for second at three-under par and [[Fred Funk]] and [[Shigeki Maruyama]] are tied for fourth at two-under par. [http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/usopen04/news/story?id=1824883 (ESPN)] * [[Rugby union]]: The [[All Blacks]] (New Zealand) defeat England 36–12 in the second test, at [[Eden Park]] in [[Auckland]]. [http://www.rugbyrugby.com/COUNTRY_BY_COUNTRY/New_Zealand/Country_News/story_36818.shtml (RugbyRugby.com)] * [[Rugby union]]: The [[Springbok Rugby Team|Springboks]] (South Africa) defeat Ireland 26–17 in the second test, at [[Newlands Stadium|Newlands]] in [[Cape Town]]. [http://www.rugbyrugby.com/COUNTRY_BY_COUNTRY/South_Africa/Country_News/story_36821.shtml (RugbyRugby.com)] * [[Rugby union]]: [[Wales]] defeats the [[Pumas Rugby Team|Pumas]] ([[Argentina]]) 35–15 in the second test, in [[Buenos Aires]]. [http://www.rugbyrugby.com/COUNTRY_BY_COUNTRY/Argentina/Country_News/story_36824.shtml (RugbyRugby.com)] * [[Rugby union]]: The [[Wallabies Rugby Team|Wallabies]] (Australia) defeat [[Scotland]] 34–13 in the second test, at [[Telstra Stadium]] in [[Sydney]]. [http://www.rugbyrugby.com/COUNTRY_BY_COUNTRY/Australia/Country_News/story_36819.shtml (RugbyRugby.com)] * [[Major League Baseball|MLB]]: [[Cleveland Indians]] [[pitcher]] [[Cliff Lee]] is suspended for six games by [[Major League Baseball]] for intentionally throwing at [[Ken Griffey, Jr.]]'s head in a game on June 13. ([http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=1824879 ESPN]) * [[2004 College World Series|College World Series]]: ** [[California State University, Fullerton|Cal State, Fullerton]] defeats [[University of South Carolina Columbia|South Carolina]], 2–0. ** [[University of Miami|Miami]] defeats [[Louisiana State University|LSU]], 9–5. * [[Boxing]]: [[Marco Antonio Barrera]] defeats [[Paulie Ayala]] by a tenth-round knockout in a Los Angeles bout highly anticipated by Mexicans and Mexican-Americans. * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]: [[Argentina|Argentinian]] [[David Nalbandian]] withdrew from Wimbledon with a torn abdominal muscle. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tennis/wimbledon04/news/story?id=1824867 (ESPN)]
==June 18, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group C – [[Italy national football team|Italy]] and [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] draw 1–1. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/euro_2004/3787519.stm (BBC)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group C – [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] beat [[Bulgaria national football team|Bulgaria]] 2–0. Bulgaria can no longer qualify for the knockout stage of the competition. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787515.stm (BBC)] * [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]]: After the second day of golf, [[Masters Tournament|Masters]] champion [[Phil Mickelson]] and [[Shigeki Maruyama]] share the lead at 6-under par at the U.S. Open. [[Jeff Maggert]] is in third place at 5-under par. Other notables include [[Ernie Els]] at −3, [[Vijay Singh]] at −2, [[Sergio García]] at even par and [[Tiger Woods]] at +1. The previous round's leader, [[Jay Haas]] shot a 4-over par on the day to finish the day at even par. [http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/usopen04/news/story?id=1824366 (ESPN)] * [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: [[Phil Jackson]] and the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] have announced, by mutual decision, that Jackson will not return to the Lakers for the next season. Jackson, the winningest coach in NBA history, had previously indicated that his return to the Lakers for a sixth season was unlikely. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=1824658 (ESPN)] * [[2004 College World Series|College World Series]]: ** [[University of Georgia|Georgia]] defeats [[University of Arizona|Arizona]], 8–7. ** [[University of Texas at Austin|Texas]] defeats [[University of Arkansas|Arkansas]], 13–2.
==June 17, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group B – [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] and [[France national football team|France]] draw 2–2. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3813635.stm (BBC)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group B – [[England national football team|England]] beat [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] 3–0. [[Wayne Rooney]] scores twice, becoming the youngest scorer in the history of these championships. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787495.stm (BBC)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: [[Italy national football team|Italy]]'s [[Francesco Totti]] is banned by [[UEFA]] for three matches for "gross sporting misconduct", effective immediately, after spitting at [[Christian Poulsen]] of [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] during their match earlier this week. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/italy/3812903.stm (BBC)] * [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]]: After the first day of play, veteran [[Jay Haas]] and [[Shigeki Maruyama]] of Japan both shot a 4-under par 66 to take an early lead before afternoon rounds were suspended because of the threat of thunderstorms. [[Ángel Cabrera]] was also at 4-under par after 12 holes before play was suspended for the day. [[Sergio García]], [[Tom Kite]] and [[Tiger Woods]] all shot 2-over par 72s. [[David Duval]], who has been absent from the Tour for several months, shot a 13-over par 83. [http://sports.espn.go.com/golf/usopen04/news/story?id=1823831 (ESPN)]
==June 16, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group A – [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] beat [[Russia national football team|Russia]] 2–0. Russia can no longer qualify for the knock-out stage of the competition. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787459.stm (BBC)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group A – [[Greece national football team|Greece]] and [[Spain national football team|Spain]] draw 1–1. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787467.stm (BBC)] * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]: The [[All England Club]] announces the seedings for the Wimbledon Championships. The number one seed on the women's side is [[Serena Williams]], followed by [[Anastasia Myskina]], [[Venus Williams]], [[Amélie Mauresmo]] and [[Lindsay Davenport]]. On the men's side, defending champion [[Roger Federer]] is the top seed, followed by [[Andy Roddick]], [[Guillermo Coria]], [[David Nalbandian]] and [[Tim Henman]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tennis/wimbledon04/news/story?id=1822955 (ESPN)] * [[NASCAR]]: [[Matt Kenseth]] and [[Kevin Harvick]] were both fined [[United States dollar|US]] $25,000 and placed on probation for intentionally spinning each other out at the end of last Sunday's [[Pocono 500]] under caution. This is in addition to the two being docked ten positions in the field for the incident immediately following the race. [http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/news/story?id=1821982 (ESPN)]
==June 15, 2004== * [[NBA Finals]]: The [[Detroit Pistons]] defeat the [[Los Angeles Lakers]], 100–87, in Game 5 of the NBA Finals to win the series and upset the heavily favored Lakers in front of a home crowd in [[Auburn Hills, Michigan]]. [[Chauncey Billups]] was named the NBA Finals MVP. * [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: Following Game 5 of the NBA Finals, [[Los Angeles Lakers]] head coach [[Phil Jackson]] says there is a "slim chance" he will return to coach the Lakers next year. [http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/wire?section=nba&id=1822735 (ESPN)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group D – [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] draw 1–1. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787535.stm (BBC)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group D – The [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] beat [[Latvia national football team|Latvia]] 2–1. [http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=150280&cc=5901 (ESPN)] * [[Tennis]]: [[Andre Agassi]] withdraws from [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] due to a hip injury, leaving the tournament without one of the world's top tennis players. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tennis/wimbledon04/news/story?id=1822116 (ESPN)]
==June 14, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group C – [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] beat [[Bulgaria national football team|Bulgaria]] 5–0, including two goals in consecutive minutes from [[Henrik Larsson]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787511.stm (BBC)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group C – [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] and [[Italy national football team|Italy]] draw 0–0. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787507.stm (BBC)] * [[Horse racing]]: Danestorm wins the [[Australian dollar|A$]]500,000 [[Brisbane|Conrad Treasury Brisbane Cup]] to give [[Kiwi (people)|Kiwi]] jockey [[Michael Walker (jockey)|Michael Walker]] his first Group 1 win in Australia. An outstanding champion apprentice jockey in New Zealand, Walker has only recently moved to Australia. * [[Major League Baseball]]: [[Philadelphia Phillies]] first baseman [[Jim Thome]] hits his 400th career home run, putting him at 37th on the all-time list ahead of [[Al Kaline]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameId=240614122 (ESPN)] * [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: Police in [[Michigan]] announce that [[Karl Malone]] of the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] will not be charged for touching a [[Detroit Pistons|Pistons]] fan on the nose before game four of the NBA Finals. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/playoffs2004/news/story?id=1821849 (ESPN)] * [[Boxing]] – The [[World Boxing Council|WBC]], one of boxing's four leading world championship organizations, closes its offices in [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]].
==June 13, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group B – [[France national football team|France]] beat [[England national football team|England]] 2–1 with two late goals from [[Zinedine Zidane]], having been 1–0 down until stoppage time. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787491.stm (BBC)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group B – [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] and [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] draw 0–0. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787487.stm (BBC)] * [[NBA Finals]]: The [[Detroit Pistons]] defeat the [[Los Angeles Lakers]], 88–80, in Game 4 of the NBA Finals to take a 3–1 series lead. No team has ever rebounded from a 3–1 deficit in the NBA Finals. * [[Test cricket]]: England beat New Zealand by four wickets at [[Trent Bridge]] to win the test series 3–0. England's [[Graham Thorpe]] hits his 14th Test century, finishing on 104 not out. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/england/3803167.stm (BBC)] * [[Football (soccer)]]: The [[Pumas de UNAM]] beat the [[C.D. Guadalajara|Chivas de Guadalajara]], 0–0 (5–4 on penalties) to win Mexico's [[association football]] championship. * [[NASCAR]]: [[Jimmie Johnson]] wins the [[Pocono 500]]. * [[Formula One]]: [[Michael Schumacher]] wins the [[Canadian Grand Prix]]. * [[24 Hours of Le Mans]]: [[Tom Kristensen (racing driver)|Tom Kristensen]] (Denmark), [[Seiji Ara]] (Japan) and [[Rinaldo Capello]] (Italy) won the 24-hour Le Mans race with a record 379 laps in 24 hours. * [[PGA Tour]]: [[Sergio García]] wins the [[Buick Open]]. * [[LPGA]]: [[Annika Sörenstam]] wins the [[LPGA Championship]], her seventh major title. * [[Rugby union]]: The [[Wallabies Rugby Team|Wallabies]] (Australia) defeat [[Scotland]] 35–15 in the first test, at the [[Telstra Dome]] in [[Melbourne]]. * [[Arena Football League]]: The [[Arizona Rattlers]] defeat the [[Colorado Crush]], 45–41, to earn a berth in [[ArenaBowl|ArenaBowl XVIII]]. * [[Boxing]]: [[Azumah Nelson]], [[Carlos Palomino]], [[Dwight Muhammad Qawi]] and [[Daniel Zaragoza]], among others, are inducted into the [[International Boxing Hall of Fame]].
==June 12, 2004== * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group A – [[Spain national football team|Spain]] beat [[Russia national football team|Russia]] 1–0. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787463.stm (BBC)] * [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]]: Group A – [[Greece national football team|Greece]] beat hosts [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] 2–1 in a surprise result in the competition's opening match. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/euro_2004/3787343.stm (BBC)] * [[NFL Europe]]: The [[Berlin Thunder]] defeat the [[Frankfurt Galaxy]], 30–24 in World Bowl XII. * [[Rugby union]]: In their first game under new coach [[Graham Henry]] and new captain [[Tana Umaga]], the [[All Blacks]] (New Zealand) defeat England 36–3 in the first test, at [[Carisbrook]] in [[Dunedin]]. * [[Rugby union]]: The [[Springbok Rugby Team|Springboks]] (South Africa) defeat Ireland 37–17 in the first test, at [[Vodacom Park]] in [[Bloemfontein]]. * [[Rugby union]]: The [[Pumas Rugby Team|Pumas]] ([[Argentina]]) defeat [[Wales]] 50–44 in the first test, in [[San Miguel de Tucumán|Tucumán]]. * [[Indy Racing League|IRL]]: [[Tony Kanaan]] wins the [[Bombardier Learjet 550|Bombardier 500]] at [[Texas Motor Speedway]]. * [[Arena Football League]]: The [[San Jose SaberCats]] defeat the [[Chicago Rush]], 49–35, to earn a berth in [[ArenaBowl|ArenaBowl XVIII]]. * [[Boxing]]: Two division world champion [[Floyd Mayweather, Jr.]] gets charged with two misdemeanor counts, stemming from two fights with women, in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=1820745 (ESPN)]
==June 10, 2004== * [[NBA Finals]]: The [[Detroit Pistons]] hold the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] to their lowest point total ever in the NBA Finals, 88–68, and take a 2–1 series lead. * [[National Hockey League|NHL]] Awards: **[[Martin St. Louis]] ([[Tampa Bay Lightning]]) – [[Hart Memorial Trophy]] (League MVP) **[[Martin Brodeur]] ([[New Jersey Devils]]) – [[Vezina Trophy]] (Best Goaltender) **[[Scott Niedermayer]] ([[New Jersey Devils]]) – [[James Norris Memorial Trophy]] (Best Defenseman) **[[Andrew Raycroft]] ([[Boston Bruins]]) – [[Calder Memorial Trophy]] (Best Rookie) **[[Kris Draper]] ([[Detroit Red Wings]]) – [[Frank J. Selke Trophy]] (Best Defensive Forward) **[[Brad Richards]] ([[Tampa Bay Lightning]]) – [[Lady Byng Memorial Trophy]] (Most Gentlemanly) **[[John Tortorella]] ([[Tampa Bay Lightning]]) – [[Jack Adams Award]] (Best Coach) **[[Jarome Iginla]] ([[Calgary Flames]]) – [[King Clancy Memorial Trophy]] (Humanitarian Contribution to Hockey) **[[Bryan Berard]] ([[Chicago Blackhawks]]) – [[Bill Masterton Memorial Trophy]] (Perseverance, Sportsmanship and Dedication to Hockey)
==June 9, 2004== * [[National Hockey League]]: Four new members of the [[Hockey Hall of Fame]] are announced: the all-time leading goal and point scorer among defensemen, [[Ray Bourque]], the second-leading goal scorer among defensemen, [[Paul Coffey]], the second-leading point scorer among defensemen [[Larry Murphy (ice hockey)|Larry Murphy]], and [[Cliff Fletcher]], former general manager of the [[Calgary Flames]] and [[Toronto Maple Leafs]]. The induction ceremony was held on November 8 in [[Toronto, Ontario]].
==June 8, 2004== * [[NBA Finals]]: The [[Los Angeles Lakers]] defeat the [[Detroit Pistons]] in overtime of Game 2 of the NBA Finals, 99–91. The game was sent into overtime by [[Kobe Bryant]], who hit a critical 3-point shot with less than three seconds remaining in regulation. * [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]: [[Larry Bird]], while commenting on the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]'s current status on an [[ESPN]] show hosted by [[Jim Gray (sportscaster)|Jim Gray]], calls the NBA, "a black man's game" and says that he would like to see more white superstars in the NBA. [http://aolsvc.news.aol.com/sports/article.adp?id=200406101035099900 (AOL Sports)] * [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA Basketball]]: [[Ohio State University]] head coach [[Jim O'Brien (basketball, born 1949)|Jim O'Brien]] was fired by the school after admitting that he gave a recruit [[United States dollar|US]] $6,000 five years ago, in violation of NCAA recruiting rules. The NCAA said they are currently investigating O'Brien and the school regarding the violation. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/basketball/ncaa/06/08/obrien.fired.ap/index.html (SI)]
==June 7, 2004== * [[National Hockey League|NHL Stanley Cup Finals]]: The [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] defeat the [[Calgary Flames]] in Game 7, 2–1 to win the [[Stanley Cup]]. The Lightning's [[Brad Richards]] wins the [[Conn Smythe Trophy]] as MVP of the Stanley Cup playoffs. * [[Major League Baseball|MLB]]: The [[San Diego Padres]] select local high school shortstop [[Matt Bush (baseball)|Matt Bush]] with the number 1 pick in the Amateur Draft.
